origin_of_ch_char_book: (èŸ², è™«, chong, insect) It features a large group of worms that have sharp heads and crawling bodies. Some worms, like caterpillars, have a poisonous sting, so that it is pointed with a sharp prick as it stings like a snake. (å¼º, qiang, strong) The left side is the bow, and the upper right is the horn of the insect that looks like a mouth , and an insect underneath that. It is a stag beetle with arched horns like a bow. Stag beetles are strong and powerful. One bite brings a great deal of pain to a person. It is therefore used as â€˜ strong â€˜.
humanum_full_description_en:
A gold inscription resembles a snake, the original meaning is a poisonous snake. "Said the text": "worm, a venomous snake Bo silver, the first big break as finger, like its shape lying.." Bronze A " worm " and " it " are like a snake, which are the " it " in The body part of the character image is relatively thick. The Oracle " it " has patterns on its body, and the inscription may be simplified as a vertical. The snake body of " Chong " is relatively small, and the two characters are not confused. (Qiu Xigui)

Oracle may refer to " worm " as "[æ­¢è™«]" (harm). For example, "Tunnan" 644: "Fu insect rain." "Tianli" 657: "Ding (Zhen): its ã¢ (has) insects (harm)." "Harmful" and "death" are ancient idioms. (Refer to Qiu Xigui) The original meaning is also used in the inscriptions, such as the fish dagger "out of the water (swim) water worm", Wang Guowei said: "About the shape of a dagger is like a worm, so it is a worm.

Simplified silk text also uses the original meaning. Such as "Shangbo Bamboo Book Eight. "Lan Fu" Jane 3: "Moths, insects and snakes." Another example is the 16-17 lines of Mawangdui's book "Laozi": "ğ§’’ (bee) ğ¤»¹ (è™¿) insect snake Fuhe (è«)." Later. The word "è™º" means the meaning of viper, which was handed down to Wang Bi's "Lao Zi. The fifty-fifth chapter" is written as "the bee, the viper, the snake does not sting".

When " worm " is used as a radical, it often refers to insects, see " roundworm ", " shu ", " bee " and so on.
humanum_short_description_en: A gold inscription resembles a snake, the original meaning is a poisonous snake. When used as a radical, " worm " often refers to insects.

Meaning Mnemonic
The insect radical and insect are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!
Reading Mnemonic
It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (ã‚€ã—) sound.
Imagine little words that say "mush" flying out from under your foot as you mush the poor thing. What does a "mush" sound sound like? You'll have to come up with something unique to yourself, and focus on it to remember this reading.
